quoteFirst: She had attached no importance to this at the time, though she had remarked to Miss Gledhow that she wished she hadn't come. The time at which the kettle flew was
quoteLast: ; at 4.25 Lady Lottie, had a sensation as though a cold hand were stroking her left cheek, the separate fingers being clearly distinguishable. Miss Gledhow had experienced a feeling all afternoon that she was being _watched and criticised_--a feeling which she could only compare to that of a person who is having his photograph taken.
title: Mad Shepherds, and Other Human Studies
author: Jacks, L. P. (Lawrence Pearsall), 1860-1955; Brooke, L. Leslie (Leonard Leslie), 1862-1940 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Though properly an evening star, shines from “dewy eve till early dawn,” rising on the 1st at
quoteLast: , and setting next morning at 6:47; and on the 31st rising at 2:21 in the afternoon, and setting the following morning at 4:42. His motion will be 9′ 9″ retrograde, and on the 12th at 7:53 p. m., he will be 55 minutes north of the moon.

quoteFirst: I lay stress upon the time--
quoteLast: --for that is the hour at which this history really begins. Then it was that a four-wheeled vehicle of a rapidly disappearing type drew up before the imposing front door of the house in Hill Street.
title: Araminta
author: Snaith, J. C. (John Collis), 1876-1936

quoteFirst: At four o’clock, as I think I have told you already, it was the old lady’s custom, if the weather was favorable, to take the air in her yellow chariot. Upon this momentous day, however, the elements were adverse; and at
quoteLast: , by the clock in the blue drawing-room, she was to be found in that spacious, somber, yet magnificent apartment. She was wearing her second-best turban, a black silk dress, and a collar of priceless old lace, secured by a brooch which was said to have been given to an ancestress by good Queen Elizabeth, who, for reasons of state, afterwards cut off the head of the recipient.
title: Araminta
author: Snaith, J. C. (John Collis), 1876-1936
